urn:contentItem:5W0N-VY71-DXH2-616X-00000-00Interview with Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin; Interview with President. Donald J. Trump about the Border Crisis; Kids II Recalls Rocking Sleepers after Five Infant Deaths; Mark Zuckerberg's Sleep Box; Marriott's Home Rental Push2019-04-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:02:37ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA7:00 AM ESTCurtis Chin, Jonathan Goldstein, Mitch Roschelle, Steven Mnuchin, Donald TrumpNEWSFinancial042902cb.231Interview with Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin; Interview with President. Donald J. Trump about the Border Crisis; Kids II Recalls Rocking Sleepers after Five Infant Deaths; Mark Zuckerberg's Sleep Box; Marriott's Home Rental PushMaria Bartiromo, Cheryl Casone, Lauren Simonetti, Judge Andrew Napolitano

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Welcome back. Good Monday morning everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo. And it is Monday, April 29th.

We're coming to you live from California this morning at the Milken Institute Conference.

Your top stories right now at 7:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

Trade is in focus today.

My exclusive interview coming up with Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

STEVEN MNUCHIN, U.S. TREASURY SECRETARY: We made a lot of progress. We couldn't be more pleased with USMCA. We hope to see the Speaker bring that to the floor so we can get it passed.

You know we signed an agreement with South Korea. We're having conversations with Europe about trade issues. We're having conversations with China. And yes, we are having conversations with Japan.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: New information on Japan coming up. More on trade, the GDP, the recent attacks on capitalism -- all right here with the Treasury Secretary.

Meanwhile, the battle at the border continues. My exclusive interview with President Trump coming up about the growing crisis that I witnessed firsthand this weekend at the border between the U.S. and Mexico in El Paso, Texas. The President says that people are illegally pouring in partly because the U.S. economy is so good. They are looking for opportunity.

There is trouble for Boeing to report. The "Wall Street Journal" is reporting this morning that the aircraft maker did not advise airlines or the FAA that it shut the warning system off on the 737 Max. What it could mean as the shareholder meeting kicks off today at Boeing.

We are also watching earnings. This is probably the biggest week so far for the first quarter reporting. Big tech companies are reporting this week, including Google parent company, Alphabet. That's today. Tomorrow it's all about Apple. We've got a preview. And then we've got the big jobs report at the end of the week.

But look at that week -- not only earnings, we've got the Federal Reserve meeting. We'll get the FOMC decision on Wednesday and, of course, trade talks as Mnuchin heads to Beijing. Full analysis on what is one of the most important weeks this week for investors

Ahead of it all, investors are looking at a market that is trading down fractionally. The Dow Industrials right now down 19 points, S&P futures down 2 and the Nasdaq futures lower by 6.

Last week the Nasdaq and the S&P 500 closed at record highs after the GDP came in better than expected. The economic growth clocking in at 3.2 percent for the first quarter. It was much better than most expectations. That's why you had a rally in the Dow of 81 points at the close on Friday, 27 points higher on the Nasdaq.

This morning in Europe, the indices are lower. FT 100 is down 9 points, the CAC 40 in Paris is lower by 15. And the Dax in Germany down by 35 points -- one quarter of 1 percent.

In Asia overnight, there's a holiday in Japan. That market is closed. But as you can see, the best performer was Korea, up 1.75 percent.

Well, the upcoming U.S.-China trade talks are on. The Nikkei average closed for Japan's Golden Week Holiday as you can see with the holiday there.

Joining me to break it all down, coming up: Fox Business Network's Lauren Simonetti is in New York this morning. PWC partner Mitch Roschelle also in New York and the Milken Institute Asia Fellow, Curtis Chin. Great to see you this morning.

CURTIS CHIN, ASIA FELLOW, MILKEN INSTITUTE: Good to see you.

LAUREN SIMONETTI, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good morning.

MITCH ROSCHELLE, PWC PARTNER: Good morning.

BARTIROMO: We really have to get your insights on all of the above.

Busy week this week. So we've got a lot to talk about. We are on it.

Our top story however, my exclusive sit-down with Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin. We talked about a wide range of topics including trade negotiations across the globe and now fears of a potential recession have certainly moved off of the front page. Policy moves at the Federal Reserve though still a focus.

We began with President Trump's economic policies and the growth that they've spurred.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

BARTIROMO: Great first quarter, 3.2 percent growth. To what do you attribute such vibrancy?

MNUCHIN: It was very impressive. And it's a result of the President's economic program. So this was tax cuts, tax reform, regulatory relief, and trade deals.

And, you know, not only was it a great number, but the first quarter is normally 1 percent lower than usual. And the government shutdown probably cost 30 basis points. This is really like a 4.5 percent unadjusted quarter.

BARTIROMO: That was incredible. So how do you keep this going? How much of a runway do all of those policies have in terms of providing a boost in the future.

MNUCHIN: Well Maria -- as you know, last year there were a lot of people who said we would never get to 3 percent. We did. Then there were people who said the economy was going to slow down.

I think the President's economic program will continue to show strength throughout this year. And the U.S. is really the bright spot of the world. We really see -- we see Europe's falling. We see China is falling. We still see tremendous amounts of money coming into the U.S. economy and I think it looks very clear for the next year.

BARTIROMO: What about Europe's slowdown? Because a lot of people feel like that has to hit the U.S. at some point. How significant is that slowdown in Europe?

MNUCHIN: Well, there's no question that the slowdown in Europe and China has already had some impact. But it just goes to show you how strong the U.S. economy is doing.

So again, I think we would be even stronger if it weren't for that. But I expect that's a modest impact.

BARTIROMO: Do you think the corporate sector is really showing the strength more so than the consumer? Is the consumer shaky? How would you characterize each sector? Consumer versus corporate.

MNUCHIN: I think as you look at each quarter, we've seen a little bit of a variation. But I think as you look it over the time period, we've seen both the consumer as well as the business sector perform extremely well. We continue to see a lot of investments in the U.S. We see more jobs. We see the participation rate going up. We see wages increasing. So this is really an across-the-board expansion.

BARTIROMO: Wages are increasing. Better than 3 percent year over year. And yet the Fed can't even get the inflation that it's targeting of 2 percent. What's your take on inflation right now?

MNUCHIN: Well, Maria -- that's good news for the U.S. economy to have this environment where we have low inflation and good growth. That's really the perfect condition we want to continue the expansion.

BARTIROMO: Is that why LARRY KUDLOW is asking for a cut in interest rates by 50 basis points? I mean if things are going so well, why is Kudlow asking for the fed to lower rates?

MNUCHIN: Maria -- you know in my position as secretary of the Treasury, I have to respect the fed independence. I'm not going to comment on interest rates.

BARTIROMO: Well, how about commenting on Kudlow?

MNUCHIN: I'm not going to comment on Kudlow commenting on interest rates either.

BARTIROMO: All right.

Well, the Federal Reserve is obviously right now saying it's out of the way, it's not going to be doing anything. But at some point with all of this strength in the economy, you would expect rates are going to go up and yet they're going down.

MNUCHIN: Well, Maria -- if you look at, you know, at the end of last year, the market expected rates to go up another 100 basis points. The markets now adjusted those expectations.

Matter of fact, at certain points there's been expectations in the market of a rate cut. I think the Fed has said they're going to be data dependent. We'll see how the data comes in and how they react.

BARTIROMO: So did it matter that we saw that inversion, the 2-year versus the 10-year yield? Usually an inversion like that indicates a recession is at hand.

MNUCHIN: No, I said at the time I wasn't concerned about the inverted yield curve and I continue not to be -- have concerns about any of that.

I think first of all, the yield curve just reflects markets. Sometimes markets are efficient and sometimes markets aren't efficient. But I don't think that was ever predicting a recession. I think it was just predicting what people expected future interest rates to be.

But, you know, there's a lot of talk about recession at the end of last year. There's no talk about recession now with people seeing these numbers.

BARTIROMO: Well, these numbers certainly indicate a much different story. You're leaving for China tomorrow. I want to ask you about China. What would be the most ideal situation in this next round of talks?

MNUCHIN: Well, Maria -- I think the good news is we've made a lot of progress. I think we've been talking about this for two years, starting with President Trump and President Xi at Mar-A-Lago talking about a desire to have a rebalanced trading relationship. And that's something President Xi agreed to.

Over the last four months, Ambassador Lighthizer and a large inter-agency team has done an extraordinary job great job. I think we've made more progress than ever before. This is a real agreement. If we get to a completed agreement it will have real enforcement provisions.

There's still some important issues. So we still have more work to do. I think we spent a lot of time, we expect to have the meetings this week. The vice premier will come back with his team the following week. I think there's a strong desire from both sides to see if we can wrap this up or move on.

BARTIROMO: Wrap this up by when?

MNUCHIN: Again, I think kind of we hope within the next two rounds of -- in China and in D.C. -- to be at the point where we can either recommend to the President we have a deal or make a recommendation that we don't.

BARTIROMO: What's most important to you? Is it most important that China opens up its markets to American companies? Is it more important that they not steal IP, forced transfer of technology? Or that they buy more stuff from the United States or that they stop espionage?

MNUCHIN: Well Maria -- I think the most important issue is that we have a rebalanced economic relationship. The U.S. has been completely open to them for investment and for goods. We want to have a reciprocal trading relationship.

And if we can do that, that's a tremendous opportunity for U.S. workers, for U.S. companies to sell into a large, growing China middle class. So if we can get this right, this will completely rebalance the economic relationship and be a great opportunity for the U.S. economy.

And there's seven different chapters. So it's not one or two issues. We have talked about forced technology transfer, intellectual property, those are very important issues. But agriculture is very important to the President, making sure that farmers are treated fairly. Financial services, currency enforcement, there are major provisions in this agreement.

BARTIROMO: Are they going to stop stealing IP from America?

MNUCHIN: We would absolutely expect them to.

BARTIROMO: So have you gotten the enforcement mechanism done? Is that agreed upon?

MNUCHIN: The enforcement mechanism is close to done. So I would say that's one of the areas we've made a lot of progress. It needs a little bit of fine-tuning. But I would say, we have a fundamental understanding in that area.

BARTIROMO: What can you say about China's economy and its impact on the U.S.?

MNUCHIN: Well, there's no question that China is slowing. But again, I think that an opening of their economy and these reforms is a very important thing for their own growth and is not only good for the U.S., but will be good for them from a domestic standpoint as well.

BARTIROMO: Is the President willing to remove all tariffs?

MNUCHIN: Again, I'm not going to comment on the specifics of our negotiations and what the President may or may not be willing to do at a specific time.

BARTIROMO: What about the espionage issue -- Secretary? Because there was a story in the "Journal" just the other day that basically says China is growing increasingly aggressive in spying on the United States and the "Journal" says "It has become Washington's single most important counter espionage priority. Is this part of the talks?

MNUCHIN: Maria -- I sit on the National Security Council, so I have access to information I can't talk about. But I would just say those issues are separate from the trade and economic issues so those are not part of the discussions we're having over the next two weeks. But there are discussions going on between us and the Chinese government on many important issues.

BARTIROMO: Well look, Huawei has been a big issue. The President has not been shy about telling us that if the Europeans, if Africa is using Huawei Telecom, then the U.S. will not share as much information with them. So clearly there has been he's espionage and trade secrets stolen.

MNUCHIN: Well, the President is absolutely determined to make sure that our communication system is secure, and whether that's China or anyone else, you know, the President is going to make sure we build out the most advanced communication infrastructure in a very secure way.

BARTIROMO: Let me ask you about Japan. The President was with Japanese Prime Minister Abe last week. Is he willing to consider putting tariffs on autos coming out of Japan?

MNUCHIN: Well, Maria -- as you know, the President has us focused on trade issues across the board. So we made a lot of progress. We couldn't be more pleased with USMCA. We hope to see the Speaker bring that to the floor so we can get that passed.

You know, we signed an agreement with South Korea. We're having conversations with Europe about trade issues. We're having conversations with China and yes, we are having conversations with Japan.

So I met with the deputy prime minister on Thursday. We had a good discussion on trade and economic issues. Ambassador Lighthizer has a team that's leading these discussions and we want to make sure that our farmers are being treated fairly and that their markets are open for our agriculture and other issues.

BARTIROMO: And the President was very clear, he doesn't want those tariffs or levies on U.S. agriculture and if they are remaining there, he would consider putting tariffs on autos coming out of Japan, right?

MNUCHIN: I think the President's going to look at all his options. But he fundamentally wants to make sure we have balanced and reciprocal trading relationships. So as you know, we have a deficit with Japan as we do in other areas. And the President is just looking for fair and reciprocal access.

BARTIROMO: So once China is completed, should we expect the President next attacks the Europeans in terms of a trade relationship and Japan? You said you're working on it right now.

MNUCHIN: Well, Ambassador Lighthizer and his team, we have a big interagency team working on all these issues. And the President has us working on all of these simultaneously.

BARTIROMO: That's incredible that you're working on all of these things together. You're in the middle of working on a deal with Japan and Europe as well as you also do China.

MNUCHIN: That's true. The economic team meets with the President weekly to update him on the trade issues. He's briefed on all these issues. He gives us input and direction. And as you know, the President is determined to make sure we have fair and balanced trade and wants to see that across the board.

BARTIROMO: The only thing is that even people who agree with all of your policies -- and it's hard not to agree. You've obviously moved the needle on economic growth. But the one thing that people say could actually change the momentum, reverse the vibrancy, are issues around trade. Do you worry that all of this conversation about the potential for tariffs on Japan, potential for increased tariffs on Europe in the face of China and all the other issues, is that going to slow down economic growth, reverse this?

MNUCHIN: Well Maria -- as you know, for a long time many of these countries didn't want to have conversations about changing the trade relationship because as the President said, we were the piggy bank and the deals were fair -- not fair to us, they were advantageous to them.

So the President is determined -- and tariffs have been a big part of getting people to the negotiating table. But the President's objective is to make sure we have fair and balanced trade.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

BARTIROMO: More of that exclusive interview coming up. We'll be right back.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

Earnings season is shifting into high gear this week -- huge week.

Cheryl Casone with the details and headlines now -- Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: I'm glad you said it like that -- Maria, huge. It is huge. We are waiting results from five Dow components this week -- Apple, Merck, Pfizer, McDonald's. And then Dow also going to post all of their results all this week. And we're going to hear from nearly one-third of S&P 500 companies, including Google's parent Alphabet, we've got General Electric and General Motors.

Now, Alphabet's results are going to be out after the bell today -- the parent of Google. That's going to be interesting. And then there's more, key economic news coming out this week. You've got the Case-Shiller Home Prices report that's out tomorrow. The Federal Reserve's decision on interest rates, that's Wednesday with a press conference and the April jobs report which you'll be covering of course, will be on Friday. Get ready.

Ok. Now, let's talk about Boeing. They're bracing for a pretty stormy annual meeting today. The company's CEO is facing shareholders for the first time since two deadly crashes of the 737 max Jet. Now Boeing reportedly did not tell airlines it had deactivated a safety feature that warns the pilots about faulty sensors until after the Lion Air crash in October. Then they started to share the information.

That safety feature was used on earlier models of the popular plane, so some of the manuals the airlines were using were actually wrong. Boeing also apparently failed to notify the FAA about the change.

Big day for Boeing today. The stock down about half a percent in the premarket.

Staying with airlines. United Airlines reportedly covering built-in cameras on certain seatback in-flight entertainment screens. A United spokesperson telling BuzzFeed the cameras that were on some premium seats were never activated. The company has no plans to use them. The decision coming after passengers began to notice the built-in cameras and they raised privacy concerns to United as well as notifying Singapore Airlines about those cameras.

Finally there is this. Massachusetts' last coal-fired power plant is now rubble.

There it went. The plant had burned coal since 1963. It closed in 2017. They new owners of the property plan to replace it with a facility that supports, Maria -- offshore wind farms. So, you know, things are changing. There you go. Back to you.

BARTIROMO: wow. Yes. That is amazing. What a picture. And that is really a sign of the times.

Thank you so much -- Cheryl.

Backlash from William Barr. The attorney general threatening not to testify this upcoming week before House and Senate Committees. This week is planned that he will testify but now there's some pushback.

Then the battle at the border. I spoke exclusively with the President on immigration -- next.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

President Trump defending himself against allegations of obstruction of justice from Judge Andrew Napolitano. The judge questioning the President's action before and after the Mueller report release.

The President wrote in a pair of tweets over the weekend about Judge Napolitano, saying this, "Thank you to brilliant and highly-respected attorney Alan Dershowitz for destroying the very dumb legal argument of Judge Andrew Napolitano. Ever since Andrew came to my office to ask that I appoint him to the U.S. Supreme Court and I said no, he has been very hostile. Also asked for a pardon for his friend, a good pal of low ratings Shepard Smith."

Joining us right now is Fox News senior judicial analyst Judge Andrew Napolitano to respond to all of this. Judge -- good to see you this morning.

JUDGE ANDREW NAPOLITANO, FOX NEWS SENIOR JUDICIAL ANALYST: Good morning.

If this is the way you treat your friends, how do you treat your enemies? Oh boy.

BARTIROMO: What happened? Did you ask him to put you on Supreme Court?

NAPOLITANO: No.

BARTIROMO: Did you ask him to pardon a friend?

NAPOLITANO: He and I spoke for about three hours in two 90-minute meetings. This is when he was the President-elect, about the type of person that should replace Justice Scalia. And in the process of my describing that person and the person I was describing was then Judge Neil Gorsuch, he looked to me and said sounds like you're describing yourself. I said no, no, I'm not describing myself. I'm describing Neil Gorsuch because you have this list of people from which you want to choose and Judge Gorsuch is the person that I think most of your advisers are going to point to.

This is early on in the process. He said all right, give me a spiel as to why I should put you on. Now who would turn that down I gave him the spiel, so-to-speak. And somebody else in the room said, you know, that's pretty interesting. The judge is a little long in the tooth to which the President said "blank you" to the person who said the judge is long in the tooth. I'm four years older than the judge and I'm about to become president.

It was that kind of conversation. So I thought the President --

BARTIROMO: And you don't expect the President -- you don't expect the President to reveal it all. But that seems like that's what he was doing, even with the pardon situations as well.

NAPOLITANO: Yes. You know, the pardon that he and I discussed is of a mutual friend of his and mine and he asked me to tell me what the person was convicted of and if I thought that the conviction was just. I described what the person was convicted of. I described that it was just. The President used a very strong term to condemn the conviction. And he said you know this person as well as I do. Call this person up and tell this person he's going to be on the list of pardons that I will seriously consider. That was the extent of that conversation.

BARTIROMO: Unbelievable.

NAPOLITANO: Look, I thought the President's comments were brilliant. He wanted to divert attention from what Mueller had said about him and what I had commented about Mueller to his relationship with me. His relationship with me is not the story. He and I have been friends for 30 years and probably will be for the next 30 years.

BARTIROMO: So let me ask about the Mueller story because Attorney General William Barr seems to be threatening that he's going to skip this hearing on the Justice Department's handling of the Russia investigation if lawmakers go through with a plan to let staff lawyers question him. Democrats are threatening a subpoena if Barr does not appear.

But you know, he's going willingly. He doesn't have to go and now they're saying that they're not even going to be there. They're going to have staff question him. What do you think?

NAPOLITANO: Well, I think they would be there. But it would be kind of demeaning to have staff questioning the attorney general.

So there's two arguments here. One is, this is the Congress' hearing and he can't tell them how to run it. The other is it's highly unusual and even improper to have persons other than elected public officials interrogating the attorney general.

Prediction? They'll work something out. The interest in this testimony is so great, they will find a way to make it happen and we'll be watching on Thursday.

BARTIROMO: Yes. All right -- Judge. Thank you so much.

NAPOLITANO: Pleasure.

BARTIROMO: Judge Andrew Napolitano. Great to see you sir. Appreciate that.

Quick break and then the border crisis. More on my visit to the southern border in El Paso, Texas yesterday. I got an up close look at how agents are working to secure the border. I spoke exclusively with President Trump during the day. His take -- coming up.

Then there's this, Mark Zuckerberg's newest invention made for his wife. We'll take a look.

Stay with us.

ANNOUNCER: Here again is Maria Bartiromo with a special edition of MORNINGS WITH MARIA live from Los Angeles at the Milken Institute Global Conference .

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. We are covering the battle at the border, part two of my exclusive interview coming up with President Trump about the growing crisis that I had a chance to witness firsthand yesterday at the border in El Paso. The president also spoke about the potential upcoming testimony of Attorney General William Barr and the pending USMCA deal. We begin with the border.

(BEGIN VIDEO TAPE)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES (via telephone): Now what's happening though is the economy is so good, you know, it's probably the best economy. You report it's one of the best economies that we've ever had. Would you say that's right?

BARTIROMO: Yes, absolutely. That 3.2 percent number obviously showed strength in the consumer as well as strength in the corporate sector because CapEx was so strong. But Beto O'Rourke, the strongest town where I am right now Mr. President helped El Paso.

TRUMP: Right. And because of that -- but Maria, because of that people see that, they're very smart. And it's the cartels, the coyotes, you wouldn't believe these people, they're tough and they're vicious, and they're smart, and they're street smart and cunning and they know the system better than the people that wrote it. They know the system a hell of a lot better than the people in Congress that wrote it. The people in Congress have no clue.

And you know, look, we have some great Republicans that are dying to get this done. They'll do anything to get it done. It's so simple. I mean, we change four or five rules and we have to change the asylum rules.

You know, the people come up asylum -- these rough gang members come up and they stand there like little innocent lambs next to a lawyer that they have who they pick up. I don't know, I guess these lawyers get paid by the -- by the dozen. And they stand there and they read a statement that the lawyer hands them. This is great danger, I am afraid for my life, I am afraid for my country and being in my country and they say oh, that's wonderful.

Then you look at the guy and you wouldn't want to fight him. OK, this guy is not afraid of anything. And you see pictures of him coming up that he's carrying a flag from Honduras or Guatemala or El Salvador.

BARTIROMO: That's right. Yes, we run into a lot of people --

TRUMP: You know, it's crazy. So you see them waving the flag proudly and then they say they're afraid to be in their country. It's just a con game.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Well, let me tell you Mr. President, I know you have to run, but you know, all of the 2020 contenders who want to run against you in 2020, you haven't heard a peep out of them about this. Beto O'Rourke is from El Paso. I don't know what he's done about this problem. And then of course, you've got Bernie and now you've got Joe Biden. They're not characterizing this as a crisis, sir.

TRUMP: So Beto O'Rourke wants to take down the walls. That means he's finished. I mean, he was finished two weeks ago when he started saying certain very stupid things. Beto O'Rourke has been exposed. I think Biden has been exposed. I don't know what the hell happened to Biden. I never saw that before. I don't know. It just doesn't look like the same Biden. I said is that really Joe Biden? He doesn't look the same to me. I've known him for a long time. I've seen him for a long time. I said what happened to him. So he's been exposed because he's very weak, he doesn't want to talk about this. No, but they don't want to talk about this.

I don't -- I don't get what their plan is. Do they they want to let people in that shouldn't be here? Because we have people that are trying to get in that shouldn't be here. Think of the word apprehend. The border security is apprehending 100,000 people a month. Do you know how many people that is? It's incredible, the job they do.

The problem is with the laws, we should be able to take them right out. We can't. We have to bring them into a court. Who ever heard of that?

BARTIROMO: I know, yes.

TRUMP: We're the only country in the world, not that I know of that has a court system and it's a -- it's a mobile court system. I mean, it is on the border and with all of these cases, 900,000 cases, you'd need to do 900 -- you'd need 100,000 lawyers. I mean, it's the craziest thing you've ever seen. So, we are doing a job.

BARTIROMO: It really is and the border patrol --

TRUMP: What we're really focused on is the bad ones. We won't let the bad ones in under any circumstances. We're keeping track of everybody. So when the laws change, we can move them back out and bring them back to their countries. So we have a very good system of keeping track. When the law is change.

Because right now, we move them out, the border patrol people would get arrested. I don't know where these people come from, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Mr. President, I know you have to go.

TRUMP: But I'll tell you, it wasn't my neighborhood. These have no common sense.

BARTIROMO: Final question Mr. President.

TRUMP: Unless -- honestly, unless they hate the country. The only thing I can say is, they hate our country. That's how stupid these laws are. There's only a person that hates our country could have approve this stuff.

BARTIROMO: Oh my God. And the whole -- the whole world loves it. They're trying to get in, in record numbers. Mr. President, before you go, real quick, William Barr testifying next week --

TRUMP: You know, people see this and they say hey, maybe -- they start learning and then they get -- you know, they get educated very quickly and you know who educates them? The cartels. And then the cartels say we want $5,000 and we'll bring you up and then the women are getting raped on the trip.

BARTIROMO: That's right.

TRUMP: The trip is brutal. The trip through Mexico.

BARTIROMO: It's very dangerous.

TRUMP: And they should do much better by the way, in stopping the people. They're not doing anything, they're doing very little for us. They should do much more. They've done more for us under me than they ever have before. But they should do much more.

They took 15,000 people out recently. But that's nothing compared to the number of people that walk. And I said, I'm going to close the border if you don't start shaping up. But Mexico is doing a terrible job.

BARTIROMO: I mean, you can't close the border though right before USMCA gets ratified though, right? I mean, you're waiting on its ratification of USMCA.

TRUMP: I'll do anything I have to, because this to me is more important than USMCA.

BARTIROMO: Mr. President, I know you have to run. Real quick, William Barr testifies next week. What's the most important question you think he should be asked, if he - if he shows up for the testimony next week, this upcoming week?

TRUMP: I think the most important question for our great new attorney general -- he's done a great job in a short period of time. I think it's just to -- how did this start, how could a thing like this happen to our country. It was a big con job. How could -- you know, top people at the FBI be so corrupt and be so rotten and why did everybody let it start?

Now, It was very interesting. I watched different people this week and everybody wants to know not about -- you know, where it came from, how did this start? Why did we come up with Bruce Ohr?

BARTIROMO: Yes, what was the predicate?

TRUMP: Why did we come up with a Comey who was corrupt? Why did McCabe and all of these people exist? I mean, McCabe whose wife got $700,000 from Hillary Clinton's PAC and she's under investigation by the -- by the FBI. No wonder she -- now wonder they let her go for so many -- so many violations. So many crimes committed. Hard to believe, actually. I mean, it's shocking.

BARTIROMO: Yes, it's all -- it's all quite extraordinary. It's all quite extraordinary.

TRUMP: And this was really a coup attempt, it didn't worked, we caught them. But now, everybody wants people to go out and find out what the hell happened, where did all of this corruption start, when you have Strzok and Page?

BARTIROMO: Well, certainly our viewers want to know.

TRUMP: The lovers we call them.

BARTIROMO: Yes, our viewers want to know that.

TRUMP: Say we wanted insurance policy --

BARTIROMO: Mr. President, thank you so much.

TRUMP: -- just in case Hillary Clinton loses, we want an insurance policy, well, we can get Trump out. Well, it didn't work so well. But I'll tell you what, it really hurt our country and it hurts our country and this is cleaning out the deep state. This is really cleaning the swamp and we've gotten rid of 22 people at the very top. These people are corrupt.

And then you look at a guy like Brennan with his big mouth and you look at Clapper who is a dummy and yet he was in Intelligence. He's a dumb guy. They lied and they lied to Congress. Clapper lied so badly it's incredible, to Congress. And then they get paid by CNN.

BARTIROMO: Yes, and we have that resume.

TRUMP: Fake news CNN, they go and they make more money than they've ever seen before, although they probably may possibly they made a lot more than that. We just don't know about it. I mean, something had to go on, but it's a disgrace.

Everyone wants to know, Maria, and you might be number one on the list, I watch your show, you're incredible. You may be number one on the list.

BARTIROMO: Thank you.

TRUMP: Everybody wants to know how did it start, why did it start, what about the dossier?

BARTIROMO: Well, we want to know.

TRUMP: How much did Hillary Clinton pay for the dossier? You know she paid for it. And the DNC paid for it.

BARTIROMO: I think it was a million dollars.

TRUMP: This guy Steele is a total fraud.

BARTIROMO: I think it was a million dollars.

TRUMP: So, you know, everybody wants to know about it. And that's really -- hopefully they'll being going there.

BARTIROMO: Mr. President, thank you so much for calling in this morning, I so appreciate it. I know you have a busy day. Thank you, sir.

TRUMP: Thank you very much, Maria.

(END VIDEO TAPE)

BARTIROMO: Coming up right here next up, booming real estate, how Marriott is now gearing up to become the first major hotel chain to create a home rental platform, they're going right after Airbnb.

And then Mark Zuckerberg's new invention, the Facebook head creates a device to help his wife get a better night sleep. We're taking a look at that. We all need it. Back in a minute.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. We're watching earnings this morning, also want to point out that J.P. Morgan is upgrading the banks this morning. We'll check the bank stocks coming up.

Then there's this, a major recall affecting rocking baby sleepers, Cheryl Casone with those details in headlines now, Cheryl.

CASONE: That's right, Maria. Kids II is recalling nearly 700,000 rocking sleepers after five infants died over the past seven years. The affected products have been sold since 2012 at Wal-Mart, Target and other stores. The Consumer Products Safety Commission says anyone who has the Kids II sleeper should stop using it. The recall comes two weeks after Fisher Price recalled about five million of its sleepers after more than 30 deaths over a decade.

All right, Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg showing off an invention that he made to help his wife sleep. It's a glowing device called the sleep box. It emits a faint light between 06:00 a.m. and 07:00 a.m., so Mrs. Zuckerberg knows the couples, two toddlers, two daughters are about to wake up without having to check her phone. Zuckerberg says if anybody wants to develop his invention further, go for it.

All right, if you like your cup of Joe with a kick, Skyy Vodka is introducing a Cold Brew Coffee flavored vodka, it's made with real coffee beans. But it's still 70 proof, folks. A liter will set you back $17.00 bottles are only available for a limited time.

And finally, I'm going to go from vodka to slime. Nickelodeon turning its signature green goo into something sweet. Wal-Mart is exclusively carrying Nickelodeon Slime Ice Cream, Maria. It's available in other vanilla ice cream cups roll with green frosting or orange, lemon lime frozen bars. I'll work on getting some for us on set.

BARTIROMO: Oh, good. Well, we'll have to -- we'll have to see that one. When I'm back in New York, I've got to see those slime -- those slime bars. Thank you, Cheryl.

CASONE: You bet.

BARTIROMO: We want to talk China and trade with Canada and Mexico. There is some question this morning, an article in the Journal, about the pushback the Democrats are giving the president on his USMCA and of course Steven Mnuchin, the Treasury Secretary is on his way to China this morning to begin another round of trade talks.

Curtis Chin is with us this morning from the Milken Institute. Tell us about the China Silk Road strategy and where China is going with this. How the U.S. gets impacted?

CHIN: Sure. Terrifically, there's so much happening this week. But one thing that happened this weekend was China's second One Belt One Road or new Silk Road initiative. It's only their plan really to help with infrastructure investments throughout the region, very positive. But maybe the negative rr they're really trying to lock in perhaps unfair relationships with trading partners from Europe to Africa, to Asia. Recreating that old Silk Road.

BARTIROMO: The president's not going to allow that. He's going to keep pushing back on China to get a deal. Do you expect a deal will in fact address some of the more important issues like the I.P. theft, like the transfer of technology?

CHIN: That's a separate issue than the One Belt One Road conference. We're very clear -- you know, we're all hopeful for a trade deal. but I think as what happened -- as what happened between the U.S. and North Korea so far, if it's a bad deal, America will walk away.

You know, the U.S. Economy, amazing, what, 3.2 percent. The U.S. is really -- economy is firing on all cylinders. And that works to Secretary Mnuchin's advantage as they try and rebalance this relationship with China.

BARTIROMO: That's a really good point. Yes, the leverage is when you've got a strong economy.

Mitch Roschelle, Lauren Simonetti in New York this morning. This article in the Journal about USMCA, we've been saying this for upwards of a year that the Democrats are pushing back on this but this would be a huge blow to markets, Lauren, if in fact the USMCA is not ratified.

SIMONETTI: I know and Democrats want labor laws changed in Mexico, particularly, in order for them to ratify this. But in the same Wall Street Journal over the weekend, Chuck Grassley wrote an op-ed. And he said essentially, look, if you want this deal to go through, you've got to take the tariffs off because the tariffs are a tax. I'm a farmer, my family's a farmer, my constituents are farmers and it hurts us.

BARTIROMO: Yes, that's absolutely right. Mitch, your reaction to that, he wants those steel and aluminum tariffs removed from Mexico and Canada.

ROSCHELLE: You know, I think sort of bridging this stories together, the thing that's interesting is as Secretary Mnuchin goes to China is the Chinese could look at what's going on with USMCA and saying wow, we're negotiating in good faith but if the Congress is going to be obstreperous and not want to play ball here, why should we bother right now? So, I wonder if they're very focused on our legislative process and going to say they've got an election coming up, they've got unfriendly Congress, maybe they don't want to be in a hurry to make a deal. So I don't know if that's part of the calculus on their part.

BARTIROMO: That's a great point. Yes, I don't think they're missing a lot, that's for sure.

We'll take a short break. When we come back, the booming real estate market, Marriott is now gearing up to become the first major hotel chain to create a home rental platform. They're going targeting right to Airbnb. My next guest will be speak here at Milken later today about just that. Stay with us.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Real estate in focus, industry leaders set to speak here at the Milken Conference later today, weighing in on the global economy, the impact on the retail, commercial and industrial real estate industries, this as Marriott International is looking to get into the home rental business, setting up direct competition with Airbnb.

Joining me right now is Cain International CEO, Jonathan Goldstein. Jonathan, it's great to see you. Thank you so much for joining us.

JONATHAN GOLDSTEIN, CEO, CAIN INTERNATIONAL: Good morning.

BARTIROMO: So, I guess some of these traditional hotel companies have seen the success that Airbnb has and they're saying I want a piece of that market share.

GOLDSTEIN: Well, I think that's right. I think over the years the hotel companies have moved very much into asset light models and now they're looking for all alternative ways they can generate revenue. And what you're seeing around the world is you're seeing the modern traveler is looking for modern ways to solve their solutions and provide ways in which they can enjoy themselves in overseas cities. I think that's a global phenomenon. I think it's going to continue growing. We're seeing it in London, we're seeing it in New York, we're seeing it in Miami. So I think we're seeing growth across the sector in all areas.

BARTIROMO: How would Marriott do it? I mean, you know, Marriott has hotels. Would they acquire homes and then rent them out? Do you know what the strategy is?

GOLDSTEIN: I would think -- I would think they would go into the world of getting people to sign up on their website and therefore creating the income by creating an income stream rather than the assets. They've stayed -- they've stayed away from the asset heavy model for some -- for some years now. And I doubt they're going back there.

BARTIROMO: Yes, this market is booming right now, isn't it?

GOLDSTEIN: It is -- it is. And I think -- we have a service department offering in eastern to the north London delivering hundred units this week. We have an opportunity at Mayfair, we have opportunities in Miami. We're seeing opportunities across the space, where alternative uses for property to meet the needs of the consumer in the 21st century. We've got a co- working space for women opening in more else place, in L.A. And of course on this site here we own -- you know, (INAUDIBLE) Beverly Hilton South where we are fortunate to be this morning where we've got a million square feet we're developing for downtown Beverly Hills.

BARTIROMO: But Jonathan, we know that the global economy is slowing. Europe is lucky to generate one percent growth this year. China has come off of the highs of the year. How is that impacting real estate right now? Are you expecting this market to slow down?

GOLDSTEIN: No, I think the world is seeing a slowdown. I think it's very important as well that people recalibrate their expectations for returns. We live in a very low interest rate environment, we've enjoyed that for over 10 years now.

So I think what was a 20 percent return, people now have to understand and expect that that's in the low teens. People have to understand their construction, they have to understand their offering. But most importantly, they have to understand the needs of the modern consumer. If they understand what people want, then they have an opportunity of meeting their needs.

BARTIROMO: That's a great point.

Let me switch gears, ask you about the U.K.'s potential exit from the European Union, being in London you have British and global real estate getting an impact there as well. Do you expect the U.K. to leave the E.U. number one, and number two, how will this impact real estate?

GOLDSTEIN: My children will tell you, I've got every political prediction wrong in the last three years.

BARTIROMO: Oh, no, OK.

GOLDSTEIN: I'm not going to say it today and make a prediction.

BARTIROMO: Not good.

GOLDSTEIN: What I will tell you is that the short-term uncertainty in Britain is chaotic. It's a farce to upper cool class there have been unable to find the solution to move forward from the vote in 2016. And I don't really see in the short-term an opportunity for that happening unless in the most extreme and unlikely situation that a conservative party led by Theresa May finds a resolution with the most left-leaning labor party in a generation.

So, I think that we've got a situation of chaos and farce. But I think we need to distinguish between the short-term and the long-term. In the long- term, you can bet on London, you can bet on the United Kingdom, we'll be OK. Thank you very much.

BARTIROMO: All right, we will leave it there. Jonathan, it's great to have you. Thank you so much.

GOLDSTEIN: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Jonathan Goldstein joining us there.

Quick break and then more of my exclusive sit-down interview with Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin. That's next. We're talking USMCA, next.

value.Title: Interview With White House Director of Legislative Affairs Marc Short; Interview With South Dakota Senator John Thune; White House Leaking; California Sanctuary Law Controversy; President Trump's Lead Attorney Quits; Trump Announces New China Tariffs; Dow Plummets

Extracts.SummaryText: ... The number of people reentering the labor force in the month of February was at the highest in 38 years, over 800,000 people coming back in. Wages are up. And we're starting to see good growth in the economy. And a lot of that, Neil, is because of policies that this president, this Congress have put in place, tax reform, regulatory reform, certainty when it comes to the legal process through the appointment of good judges to the courts. Those are all things that I think are shaping the ...

<xhtml:span id="h1" class="hits-fragment" xmlns:xhtml="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml">... from these tariffs. Add to that what's going on with the <xhtml:span class="hit">big tech</xhtml:span> companies and the <xhtml:span class="hit">regulatory</xhtml:span> framework that's most likely coming. <xhtml:span id="h2" class="hits-fragment" xmlns:xhtml="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml">... that this president, this Congress have put in place, tax reform, <xhtml:span class="hit">regulatory</xhtml:span> reform, certainty when it comes to the legal process through the ...</xhtml:span>
