urn:contentItem:5RXV-9GX1-JB20-G0K3-00000-00Interview With White House Director of Legislative Affairs Marc Short; Interview With South Dakota Senator John Thune; White House Leaking; California Sanctuary Law Controversy; President Trump's Lead Attorney Quits; Trump Announces New China Tariffs; Dow Plummets2018-03-22T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:02:37ZLexisNexisYOUR WORLD WITH NEIL CAVUTO4:00 PM ESTMichelle Steel, John Thune, Marc Short, Brad Blakeman, Lisa GiovinazzoNEWSInternational032203cb.140Interview With White House Director of Legislative Affairs Marc Short; Interview With South Dakota Senator John Thune; White House Leaking; California Sanctuary Law Controversy; President Trump's Lead Attorney Quits; Trump Announces New China Tariffs; Dow PlummetsCatherine Herridge, John Layfield, Peter Doocy, John Roberts, Neil Cavuto

THIS IS A RUSH TRANSCRIPT. THIS COPY MAY NOT BE IN ITS FINAL FORM AND MAY BE UPDATED.

NEIL CAVUTO, HOST: Yikes, the Dow, the lawyer, and, oh, yes, the trade war.

FOX on top of more than just stocks going down. And, boy, oh, boy, did they ever go down. The Dow careening more than 723 points on a trifecta of troubles that all came together today.

First up, the president's lead attorney out, John Dowd quitting, the same John Dowd who was strongly advising that the president not sit down with Bob Mueller.

Second up, tariffs. Try more than $50 billion worth of them going down, China the target. And let's just say today China not happy.

And third up, a $1.3 trillion spending plan that passes in the House, but is anyone's guess in the Senate. If it fails, guess what? The government shut down, which, as I said, all combined have sent stocks down. Every single Dow component in the red today. The Dow surrendering more than 722 points for the day, down about 3 percent, the Nasdaq almost 2.5 percent, the S&P 500 2.5 percent.

More on what produced those numbers.

First to the White House on how they're responding to them.

That's where you will find our John Roberts -- John.

JOHN ROBERTS, FOX NEWS CHIEF WHITE HOUSE CORRESPONDENT: Well, clearly, Neil, as the Dow has continued to go down since the president made his announcement that he sending his U.S. trade representative, Robert Lighthizer, to the drawing board to come up with some tariffs against China and then further to that take some measures to restrict investment by China in U.S. technological companies, they have watched the Dow tick down and tick down.

And now we're back -- we're down over 700 points. And the president, of course, all through the campaign and the first part of his presidency was touting at how the Dow was at record numbers. Now it looks like it's on a little bit of shaky ground.

But let's not also forget that when the president was doing the run-up to tariffs on steel and aluminum, the Dow was all over the place and it managed to recover quite well. So the president and the White House clearly hoping that this is only a temporary setback as well and that when they see the effect of the tariffs might be, if and when tariffs are actually imposed, the Dow may decide that it's not as flipped out as it appears to be today.

Let's not forget that the tariffs on steel and aluminum have not been imposed yet. Now to a couple of the other things. A $1.3 trillion budget clearly is something that the stock market doesn't like, because that means that the deficit will be even bigger than it was, adding to the debt.

And that's always a drag on the stock markets as well. And then there's the report that came out this morning about the president's lead outside attorney, John Dowd, is leaving the legal team. One of the reasons for that is that it appears as though there was a conflict between members of the outside and the inside legal team, each other and with the president, over what the future strategy should be.

The president appeared to be not listening to the advice of John Dowd, who was urging cooperation with Mueller, but at the same time suggesting that the president shouldn't sit down for an interview with Mueller, or if he did, that the parameters of that be very narrow.

We saw Joe diGenova, the famous former U.S. attorney for the District of Columbia and a man that believes that there was a conspiracy at the top of the FBI to frame President Trump for a false crime, being named to the legal team. They also reached out to Ted Olson, John Flood, a number of other people they're also reaching out to try to try to bolster that team.

So, just seemed that John Dowd wasn't fitting in with the team as it was organizing to go forward in what they believe will be a crucial aspect of the Mueller investigation.

But the president when asked this afternoon in the Diplomatic Room after announcing the trade action on China, saying that he would like to sit down for an interview with Mueller. Another indication that that may be not in not-too-distant future -- Neil.

CAVUTO: All right. Buddy, thank you very, very much, John Roberts.

All right, before I go to my guests here, I do want to show you happened at the corner of Wall and Broad and a sell-off that picked up steam. Again, as I said, all Dow 30 components were down and appreciably so. This is now putting the Dow into correction territory yet again.

And we had some technology stocks that were falling off beyond that. Boeing, for example, was one of the worst performers in the Dow, falling better than 5 percent. Remember, a lot of people seem to think that Boeing more to that point is going to be a target of the Chinese as a sort of a tit for tat on all of the beefed-up tariffs that the administration is looking to slap on the Chinese. That's the next stage of this.

We're also looking at that $1.3 trillion spending measure which worried Wall Street even though it passed the House because it's just chockful of all these goodies and the spending that seems to know no bounds.

We're going to be going to Peter Doocy on Capitol Hill with that and a read on that, but first of John Layfield on the market responding to all these developments, sort of lick a trifecta of trying news, huh?

JOHN LAYFIELD, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: It is.

We knew this day of reckoning was coming, that the easy money was going to end, that rates were going to start going up. But I think what has exacerbated it obviously was inflation worries that are coming up, but more importantly the tariffs and the retaliatory trade that could come from these tariffs.

Add to that what's going on with the big tech companies and the regulatory framework that's most likely coming. I think you have this big storm that we have had it today.

CAVUTO: Now, Kevin Brady, the House Ways and Means chief, John,, has talked about the fact that trade tariffs -- and the president might be right to be chagrined about this. He doesn't like the way some of these countries play ball, but that a trade war could wipe out all the benefits of the tax cuts.

Is that among some of the factors hitting stocks?

LAYFIELD: I don't think there's any doubt about.

It's hard to put tariffs on China because they have a global supply chain. Not everything is made in China. We learned that in 2009 with President Obama when we put the tire tariff on. It didn't work. All we did is get tires from different places. It didn't work. we didn't have any more production necessarily in the United States coming from that.

But, however, China can put tariffs on us directly. They can put it on our farm products. They can put it on our technology. That's much easier to do. A retaliatory measure from China hurts us more than it hurts them.

CAVUTO: All right, we're seeing a the bottom of the screen, for those looking at home here, a correction is when you're 10 percent from your highs. A bear market starts at 20 percent from those highs.

But one of the catalysts besides trade that might be influencing this is this touch and go thing with a spending measure to keep the government lights on for another six months or at least through the next fiscal year, at least through the end of this one.

And that's where we will find our Peter Doocy sort of dealing with this.

It's a $1.3 trillion measure, right, Peter? And it passes the House, but iffy in the Senate? What's the latest?

PETER DOOCY, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: The latest right now, Neil, is that there are big question marks not -- about certain senators who may not want a vote to proceed before the government shutdown deadline.

And, in fact, we came over here to Senator Rand Paul's office. We were talking to some staff. We understand that he is in here right now trying to read this 2,232-page bill, but right now he's only on page 140.

There's no updated guidance right now as to whether or not he is going to object to a vote that would let them pass this omnibus budget and avoid a government shutdown or he's going to try to block it. But he's not the only Republican senator who has problems with this.

Senator Bob Corker, Republican retiring from Tennessee, was on the Senate floor a little while ago. He said that this bill is one of the most grotesque pieces of legislation that he has ever seen.

And a big problem that these fiscally conservative Republican senators have is just that you spend a lot of new money and you don't make any new meaningful cuts elsewhere -- Neil.

CAVUTO: Now, the question, Peter, is what happens if the Senate can't get its act together on this? Time is a ticking, right? I mean, by 12:01 Saturday morning, bright and early, they don't have something together, the pumpkins explodes, right?

DOOCY: Right.

And then in the first three months of the midterm election year, you would have your third government shutdown. And that would come as a surprise to a lot of people on Capitol Hill, because even though the HouseFreedom Caucus, the conservative lawmakers over there, have been urging President Trump not to sign this measure, Republican leadership put enough stuff into this omnibus that they were able to get more than a hundred Democrats on board over there.

There's a lot of Democratic support in the Senate. In fact, Chuck Schumer had a press conference a little while ago where he said that they were happy with the deal that they got, which is not something that you hear from Republicans, except those who were very pleased with all the new Pentagon spending.

But if there is a shutdown, then you're just going to hear a lot more talk about dysfunction, about waiting until the last minute, but also about why Republicans, who were elected to come to Congress to rein in spending, haven't been doing that -- Neil.

CAVUTO: All right.

Guys, thank you all very, very much -- Peter Doocy.

White House Legislative Affairs Director Marc Short with us right now.

Marc, a confluence of weird events here, but the worry seems to be that there could be some hell to pay with this stuff. I know you don't obsess over the markets to the degree maybe your boss did when they were going and running up, but are you worried?

MARC SHORT, WHITE HOUSE DIRECTOR OF LEGISLATIVE AFFAIRS: Well, Neil, I think, putting it in perspective, the markets were a little over 18000 on Election Day 2016. So, we have had about a 30 percent increase in the markets.

You have unemployment at a 17-year low. You have the Fed announcing just yesterday, when they raised rates, expectations of continued reduced unemployment and actually boosting their GDP forecast.

So the fundamentals of our economy remain strong. The president's policies on regulations and taxes continue to boost our economy. And now what the president is looking to do is to try to protect American workers and American companies whose intellectual property has been stolen by the Chinese.

CAVUTO: You had said and the president had echoed that you weren't fans necessarily of this $1.3 trillion spending plan, but it allows you to move forward. You get what you want on the military and some of these other priorities. Some of the Democrats get what they want. And it should pass.

What if it doesn't?

SHORT: Well, Neil, we fully expect the bill to pass. As far as to when I think is a guess, for tonight, tomorrow night.

But the reality is that Congress has provided us with six continuing resolutions since the fiscal year ended on September 30. What that means is that rather than actually doing their job and passing appropriations bill, we're stuck with legislation that General Mattis tells us puts them at a great handicap, because they're basically repairing old, worn-out equipment, as opposed to purchasing new equipment they need to continue to fight the war on terror.

So, from an administration perspective, you're right. There's a lot things in the bill we like. We like that is the first, the most significant pay increase for our men and women in uniform in 10 years. It's the biggest build-up in military resources since World War II that can help make sure that America safe.

It does provide a lot of the border security measures. It does provide legislation that we were asking for as far as protecting our schools and making them safer.

But the price tag is something that, if we had sufficient Republican votes, of course we wouldn't want as much non-defense spending is in this bill. But, ultimately, we have to make a decision as administrations, do you shut down the government, have another continuing resolution, or actually provide our troops the resources they need to make sure America is safe?

CAVUTO: This tariff thing, any response from the Chinese yet? They have promised that they're going to do something. They vowed all necessary measures. They deny that they force companies to hand over technology, some of the things that the president outlined.

But they are almost assuredly going to target U.S. companies or even industries or even the agriculture community, that they could go after our farmers. Are you worried that this gets out of control?

SHORT: Well, Neil, I don't think any of us wants a trade war. And we certainly want to protect the farmers in America. And I know that China looks at that and knows how much of the agricultural products they import.

But at the same time, for decades, we have had administrations talk about the intellectual theft. It's nothing that is just an accusation. It's something that's been documented and proven, when basically they force American companies to partner with them. They steal the intellectual property. And they will go set up competing companies inside China that's owned by a communist government.

So the practices have been grossly unfair. This administration's trying to do something to make sure that American intellectual property is protected.

CAVUTO: Let's talk about where this goes, because many on Wall Street have were rattled by that.

They have memories that trade wars have started and they sort of can't stop. They just grow and grow. You're clearly not worried about that.

But I'm wondering what kind of advice the president is getting from foreign leaders, other countries who all say, almost to a country, that be careful what you start here, Mr. President, German finance minister, a number of others?

Do you fear that it's going to get in the way of some of the other deals you hope to make with some of these same foreign players, the Chinese included, on other big items?

SHORT: Well, my role, obviously, is working more with Capitol Hill.

And I can tell you there's a lot more bipartisan support for these actions on China. I think members in Congress have been anxious to see this for quite some time.

CAVUTO: Well, I don't know. I don't know, Marc.

Kevin Brady., the House Ways and Means chief, does worry about this wiping out the benefit of those tax cuts that you guys worked very hard to get. Are you worried?

SHORT: Well, actually, in some of our meetings here in the White House, Kevin Brady has reiterated his support for going after China and believing that they are stealing our intellectual property.

So as we focus on the 301 measure, I think there actually is broad bipartisan support for it.

CAVUTO: All right, so, ultimately now with the markets -- and you're quite right to say, I mean, the trend has definitely over the course of the this president's tenure in the White House been very, very productive.

But, you know, like you say, people look for a correction, they look for a reason to move back. And there's this fear that all of a sudden spending is out of control again, and we're looking at likely a trillion-dollar deficit now, and that the timing couldn't be worse for the midterm elections and all of that. What do you say to that?

SHORT: Well, again, I think it's a one-day reaction in the markets.

I would look at the long term trend. I would certainly expect as we continue to roll back the regulatory front, we continue to make sure that this administration is working with business across America, including in this case trying to protect their intellectual property, I think the markets will respond affirmatively.

And as I said, just yesterday, you saw testimony from the new Fed chairman saying that the unemployment rate is actually expected to continue to drop and growth now at high -- elevating their forecast as to how high we're going to go.

CAVUTO: And the irony of that is that good news was greeted as a concern, because the better things look, the more likely he will keep raising interest rates more than was originally thought to be the case.

What do you think?

SHORT: Well, I think that we have had such historically low interest rates that, in many cases, the growth that we saw during the Obama years, when for eight years GDP only grew at 1.8 percent, in many cases, that was artificially low by a Fed keeping interest rates so low.

CAVUTO: You're right about that.

SHORT: The reality is that -- the reality is, yes, Neil, you're right, there is -- as you grow, that -- that higher interest rates could begin to slow that growth. That is certainly a concern.

But we have had so historically low, artificially low rates, that actually you're seeing a response to growth. And in some cases, you're seeing a response to wage inflation, which is something Americans have been dying for, for many years.

So a lot of this is actually, as you say, a reaction to very positive news.

CAVUTO: This might not be your area exactly, Marc, but if you will indulge me.

John Dowd stepping down as the president's lead attorney, did he quit or was he pushed?

SHORT: You know, Neil, I apologize, but that's just not an area that I'm working in, and I'm not familiar with the inside conversations on that.

CAVUTO: Were you surprised?

SHORT: Neil, I don't know what extent there is surprise.

I think, that as we have expressed many times, there's a growing frustration of the length and duration of the special counsel investigation into collusion with Russia, when there's been no evidence of whatsoever of collusion with Russia.

And I think that taxpayers have spent millions and millions of dollars on this so far.

CAVUTO: You're right. There's a great deal of attention to this entire case and where this whole case will go.

And the president now has mentioned Bob Mueller's name when he talks about this. A lot of Republicans are saying, go slow there, be careful about that there.

Was there concern building among some of the people you talk to, because you work legislatively with the other side of Capitol Hill, that the president is going too far?

SHORT: No, I don't think so, Neil.

I think that the administration has had many conversations with members on the Hill on this topic. And I think that, typically, what we're hearing is an affirmation from many Republicans that there's no been evidence in their investigations of collusion with Russia. And I think that there's, I think, a growing frustration in the American people that this continues to drag on.

CAVUTO: You have been very patient.

SHORT: Yes, sure.

CAVUTO: But I want to get sort of a big picture view of the White House of what comes next.

In order to look at these tariffs that have been slapped on the Chinese, and no response as of yet, let's assume they make a decision over the weekend to target either an industry or Boeing, for example, Boeing plane orders.

Is there a plan for a follow-up response to that response?

SHORT: Well, Neil, I'm not going to put out a hypothetical response as to how the administration will respond.

CAVUTO: Feel free. Feel free. Go ahead.

SHORT: No, no, no, no, no.

No, but, again, I think I come back to making the case that this administration is going to continue to make sure that the American worker is protected. And that was a priority the president laid out in the campaign. This is something he talked about for quite some time.

It actually, I think, as I said, has bipartisan support. And I don't think there should be surprise over it.

CAVUTO: All right, now, very quickly back to this measure, this $1.3 trillion spending measure.

SHORT: Yes.

CAVUTO: It's your hunch that this is ultimately passed and we avoid a government shutdown?

SHORT: Yes, it is, Neil.

I think that, again, the process in Washington has been broken for quite some time. They have not completed a normal appropriations process in 22 years.

For your viewers, we submit a budget in February that Congress is supposed to complete by September 30. We're now in mid to late March without having that process completed, which is why you have these large omnibus bills.

I can't sit here and tell you and your viewers that we love everything in the bill. It's the nature of a compromise. But we think that we got many of our priorities funded, particularly funding our military and making sure that we're getting resources to begin the down payment in building the wall the president's promised.

CAVUTO: Now, you're the legislative affairs director.

I'm sure you're aware of the Freedom Caucus, a conservative group of Republicans, not a fan of this latest spending plan, saying that it's not consistent with what we told the American people. We have let them down. You have heard variations of that argument from some of their members.

How do you keep them happy? And are you worried that right now they're not?

SHORT: Well, the Freedom Caucus has been some of our greatest partners in our legislative accomplishments to date.

They partnered with us on the tax relief legislation. They have partnered with us significantly in rolling back the regulatory burden that the Obama administration had on this economy. So, we maintain, I believe, very strong relationships with the Freedom Caucus.

I understand their perspective. Again, from a White House perspective, what we say back to Congress is, put your own house in order and put the process in place that you can get us appropriations bills on time.

Otherwise, we won't have to deal with a large omnibus. But in light of Congress not doing its job, we have -- we're put in a position of, do you want another shutdown, or are we going to give Secretary Mattis the resources he needs to make sure America is safe, make sure that DHS has the resources it needs to begin protecting our border?

It has a 10 percent increase in funding for ICE, about a 12 overall increase in DHS funding. And it also provides some of the priorities the president said after the tragedies with the school shootings and providing for the Stop School Violence Act, as well as opioid dollars we have asked for, as well as beginning a down payment on the infrastructure plan.

So there's a lot of things in this bill that we had asked for and we're pretty excited about.

CAVUTO: All right, Marc Short, thank you very much for taking the time.

Marc is the White House legislative affairs director. We threw a lot at him in this interview.

Thank you, Marc, again.

All right, for those of you just tuning in, and you want to know what the heck happened today, this was it. And this shows the bumpy ride we had through the course of the day. This is, of course, the time we got indicated that the probe, the Russian probe is going to have a top lawyer at the White House out.

Then you had the tariff news, and you had the spending news, a measure that did pass, which world be greeted favorably normally, but the fact that it will be dicey in the Senate or the fact that it's just going to add to our debt, which is already substantial, combined as a sort of 1-2-3 hit for the markets here, and something that picked up steam by day's end.

And Marc is quite right to point out that, even with today's hit, we're only in correction territory now, in other words, back 10 percent from our highs. The Nasdaq actually is not in correction territory, even though the Nasdaq 100, some of those hot, fast stocks like Facebook and others that have problems of their own, that's down 5.6 percent from its highs here.

But a lot of this had to do with the simple fact of an excuse to sell or reason to sell or impetus to sell or Washington out of control, whatever you want to say. Facebook, again, its own little separate soap opera that we are going to get into it.

But I will tell you this. A lot of money was going into bonds. A lot of money was going into something called the 10-year note. And a lot of people use that. And this can sound kind of gobbledygook boring, but a 10- year note fell seven basis points today.

That's a sign that money was going into bonds today, a relative safe haven, because they're backed by Uncle Sam. And that drove the yield down a little bit to 2.83 from 2.90 percent.

Now, you say, Neil, why do you mention that? Because money was trying to find a home. At least a lot of stock traders will tell you a temporary home, because they want them back in the stock market.

So, as crazy as this incredible day was, it's worth pointing out that the markets are up still appreciably. The only question is, let's just see what the Senate does with that spending plan. Let's just see what the Chinese do with that tariff plan. And let's just see what other lawyers are moving around on Pennsylvania Avenue.

That, my friends, is the making of a Washington drama. It was playing out in real time.

More after this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

QUESTION: Mr. President, would you still like to testify to special counsel Robert Mueller, sir?

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: Thank you.

QUESTION: You would?

TRUMP: I would like to.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CAVUTO: It makes it easier if someone is walking by that you can see letters of what they're saying.

But that was the president saying that he would be open to talking about Bob Mueller, of course, doing this Russian investigation.

Now, keep in mind John Dowd, the president's top attorney, stepping down lot today. He was among those -- actually the only one, as far as I know, urging the president not to sit down with Bob Mueller. Others within the White House, the legal team, both from the White House and the president's himself, have been trying to come up with a way, a middle ground, either written questions of responses, targeted area that will talk about.

Our own Judge Andrew Napolitano says, that would be a very big mistake, that it sets the stage for something that the president will not like.

Attorney Lisa Giovinazzo says she agrees with that, that a sit-down there, whatever your views of the subject, for the president at least, could be a problem.

Why is that, Lisa?

LISA GIOVINAZZO, ATTORNEY: Look, no defense attorney want their clients to sit down in here an Q&A with authorities.

Immediately, you're at the risk of perjury. Miranda rights, right, anything that you can say can and will be used against you, this all ensues.

And there's no reason for him to do it.

CAVUTO: Now, is the fear that he says something that goes beyond what he intended to or that he would veers into an area that he had no idea would be discussed?

If his lawyers are presently looking at a structured area where he could or would either via written responses or others talk about stuff, just as long as he's aware of the stuff they're going to talk about.

GIOVINAZZO: Well, I mean, the written responses, right, they would go along the lines of interrogatories. That's kind of the first step.

And they're always profitable, because you can look at them. The lawyers can help him draft the proper responses. They're very focused, whereas you put anybody in a room, especially President Trump, and every word now will be taken literally. And that could be a very dangerous scenario.

We also have a president and an investigation that has a pretty wide net. If you remember back in the Clinton days, he did sit down with the prosecutors.

CAVUTO: He did.

GIOVINAZZO: And it didn't work out very well for him, but it was also a very focused investigation. This not so much.

There a lot of different areas that the president could delve into. Now, the one positive, he would be able to have counsel in the room.

In the event that he doesn't have a sit-down, there is always the risk that they could choose to subpoena him.

CAVUTO: Where you think this is going, Lisa?

GIOVINAZZO: The fact that he recently fired Dowd, the fact that he goes through a lot of lawyers at the time, I don't think that he is all that concerned with the criminal nature of this investigation.

I think it's much more political. I think that it's gotten a lot of legs because it keeps coming up with a lot of changes, a lot of legalese we're hearing about.

But in the nature of this case, it's a long way out. Even if they were to subpoena him, that could be months in a court system. They have never subpoenaed a sitting president and actually enforced it against him

I mean, they're -- the scales of justice, they work, but they turn very slowly.

(CROSSTALK)

CAVUTO: But they're maddening for the president.

I can understand that. I mean, obviously, this investigation seems to have gone afield from what it was originally. Now they're looking at business transactions that date to the Trump organization and years before even he was running for president, if we're to believe these reports.

So, it wouldn't be the first investigation that has gone from its original intent. I'm thinking of Whitewater with Ken Starr. That was about land deals and the like. And it ended up with an intern in a blue dress.

So, where is this going?

GIOVINAZZO: Well, I think you hit the nail on the head.

I think it's going into deeper and deeper areas of the president's personal business, because they're not getting what they want to come up with an indictment, to find criminal charges on the surface, which is why this whole -- this whole issue about Q&A with the president is coming up.

They don't seem to have enough to move forward. And that's why you're hearing from other people in the party. You're hearing from his lawyers to say, you know, move with it or drop the investigation.

And, honestly, he does have a right to that. People have a right to a speedy trial. Now, bear in mind, it's just an investigation. Nobody -- nobody is pointing a finger at the president. So he's kind of stuck in this gray area that it could really drag out for a very long time.

And I think that all of us would agree that we're starting to see a lot of political movement in this investigation, and the fact that it doesn't seem to ever come to an end.

CAVUTO: Yes, just accelerates, like a soap opera as well.

GIOVINAZZO: Yes.

CAVUTO: Lisa, thank you very, very much. Good seeing you.

GIOVINAZZO: You too, Neil.

CAVUTO: All right, the read from one of the most powerful Republicans in the United States Senate, John Thune, on what's going on here and what is going on with that spending measure.

Remember, it has to get passed in the Senate and have to do so in a little bit more than, what, 30 hours or so, or we're looking at a government shutdown. Are we? John Thune after this.

CAVUTO: All right, a big hit in the Dow today.

In case you're counting, all 30 Dow stocks are down, and all 11 sectors of the S&P 500, they were down as well. Try 1,000 points on the Dow just this week. We have another day to go.

After this.

CAVUTO: All right, we just want to pass along some news regarding the Trump administration approving $1 billion worth of arms sold to the Saudi Arabians.

Remember, the crown prince is visiting this country for the next couple of weeks. He had stopped by at the White House to visit the president just a couple of days ago. That order will include more than 6,500 missiles.

He expressed concern -- that is, the crown prince, as well as the president -- about Iran and that nuclear agreement that seems to be fraying and falling apart.

We should let you know right now that the Saudis have made clear that if the Iranians get their hands on a nuclear weapon, he wants to go nuclear himself.

The read on all of this and all the other news happening today from South Dakota Republicans Senator, prominent top Republican, John Thune.

Senator, good to have you.

SEN. JOHN THUNE (R), SOUTH DAKOTA: Nice to be with you. Thanks, Neil.

CAVUTO: What do you make? I mean, this is still early.

One billion, I guess for the Saudis and us, is chump change these days, but it's a pretty big missile deal. And we seem to be very tight with both the Saudis, helping them, and them helping us. What do you make of this arrangement?

THUNE: Well, I think they have been an ally for a long time on a lot levels.

And, obviously, right now, they help check in that region of the world the influence of Iran. And I think it's important for us to continue to maintain that relationship and to work together with them as partners to try and bring stability to that region of the world.

They are leading the force against -- in Yemen. They're helping the government there against the Houthis, which are backed by the Iranians. And so there are lots of ways in which our countries are able to cooperate. And I think we continue -- need to continue that if we're going to keep some sort of a stability in that region, which is so important to the stability of the entire world.

CAVUTO: You know of the markets, as you're aware, Senator. Of course, you're not as much as a nerd as me and live and die by this stuff, so touche to you.

But there's a fear expressed by some traders of all political persuasions that what goes but is coming down. It's coming down again. Washington spending is out of control. You guys can't seem to agree on this. Maybe you do the measure on the spending plan to avoid a government shutdown, but that the debt is building, a lot of excesses are building, and there's a world of hurt coming, including now a potential trade war with the Chinese.

Are you concerned?

THUNE: I am.

I think there are a lot of things that we need to be concerned about. We have got to get spending under control. We have got to deal with this debt and this deficit, which, of course, I think means we have got to reform our budget process.

But we have to play the long game. The market has its day-to-day ups and downs and gyrations, but I think as long as we focus on policies that are creating conditions that are favorable to economic growth, and we're seeing that -- you saw the unemployment rate is now down to its lowest level in 17 years.

The number of people reentering the labor force in the month of February was at the highest in 38 years, over 800,000 people coming back in. Wages are up. And we're starting to see good growth in the economy.

And a lot of that, Neil, is because of policies that this president, this Congress have put in place, tax reform, regulatory reform, certainty when it comes to the legal process through the appointment of good judges to the courts.

Those are all things that I think are shaping the economy right now in a way that provides hope and optimism for the future, which is why consumer confidence is up.

That said, we have to -- we have got to get fiscal discipline back in place here in Washington.

CAVUTO: But it's nowhere near -- it's nowhere near in place, right?

The HouseFreedom Caucus, they just threw up their arms and said, oh, no one seems to care about it. Republicans run the show. They have the House, the Senate, the White House, and yet this debt is growing faster than me circling a Ponderosa buffet.

No?

THUNE: Well, it's two things.

We have got to reform entitlement programs, which the Democrats have had no appetite for. We tried to do that with the Obamacare replace and repeal last summer. We put in place for the first time real entitlement reforms in the Medicaid program.

Obviously, that failed by a vote. We need more Republicans, more conservatives in Congress to get the entitlement programs reined in. That's the spending side.

But on the other side, as I mentioned earlier, you got to have growth in the economy. And that's why these policies that are pro-growth and pro- jobs are really important. And so it's a -- it's a combination of both.

It's fiscal restraint, but it's also pro-growth policies. And I think we can get this back on the right track. But it does start fundamentally, in my view, with reforming our budget process. And that's something that I and many others around here have been advocating for a long time.

And I hope that, again, another omnibus spending bill like this will renew the emphasis on serious, meaningful budget reform here in Washington.

CAVUTO: Are you worried about a trade war?

THUNE: Well, I am worried about what I see happening out there. I do think that that could undermine a lot of the good things that we're seeing in the economy.

And the market obviously is reacting to it. But I think, again, we want to make sure that when we -- these trade policies -- and I understand the president's desire to clamp down on China and to deal with them in a way that helps them understand that we are serious and that they're going to have to get serious when it comes to stealing our intellectual property, but that we do that in a way that doesn't create disruption in the market.

And, obviously, we're worried about retaliatory actions taken particularly directed at agriculture that could be very detrimental and harmful to the middle of the country, but to the whole country.

And so this is one of those things, they need to proceed slowly with care, very targeted, very selective in how they go about this. I think these indiscriminate, wide tariff policies could be incredibly harmful if they lead to an escalation of a trade war.

That's not going to be good for the economy in the long term.

CAVUTO: You think the president made a mistake?

THUNE: I disagree with him on this issue.

I know he feels passionately about it. I have heard him speak about it. I do think that he wants to see reciprocal trade. We agree with that. But, again, I think how you go about that, the policies you implement, who you direct those at, thinking about the consequences and the unintended consequences and how those retaliatory actions might occur, what they might hit, being prepared for that is going to be really important.

And so I hope, as they move forward, they do it in a very thoughtful way, and in a way that would limit the ancillary, harmful and adverse impacts that could occur to the economy.

I appreciate the fact they have scaled back some of these actions already. But I guess I would encourage them not to get us in the middle of a trade war. I don't think that is in anybody's best interests. And I think it could undo a lot of the good progress that we have seen in terms of economic growth as a result, in many respects, because of the president's policies and working with the Congress.

CAVUTO: All right, Senator John Thune, very good having you. Thank you.

THUNE: Thanks, Neil. Appreciate it.

CAVUTO: All right.

And speaking of the Senate, that measure, that budget measures could come up tonight, could come up tomorrow. But it's got to get done before 12:01 a.m. on Saturday, or we do have another shutdown.

We shall see.

CAVUTO: All right, you're familiar with what's going on at Facebook right now, and how that stock has just been getting pummeled over the last few days over the release of information that showed 50 million folks had their data compromised.

Well, the stock has swooned, lost about $40 billion in market value, about $8 billion of that, well, for Mark Zuckerberg. That is how much poorer he is this week, $8 billion poorer. A rounding error on his worth, but I thought I would pass that along.

All right, first, it was Los Alamitos, remember that, proposing to opt out of California's new sanctuary law. Now many other government officials there, elsewhere saying, you know what? We want a sanctuary from this sanctuary thing, because it's killing us.

Orange County Supervisor Michael Steel, who proposed just last night to take on the issue at her next meeting.

Michelle Steel.

I apologize, Michelle.

CAVUTO: What kind of reaction are you getting?

MICHELLE STEEL, ORANGE COUNTY SUPERVISOR: I got a lot of support, because people are sending me a lot of e-mails. And they strongly support, because they know that California law, that Senate Bill 54 is illegal.

So I get a lot of support and a lot of phone calls. And I really appreciate that.

CAVUTO: Your argument is what, that this hurts you. Explain why you're doing this.

STEEL: Well, the government's first duty, I believe that that is protect its citizens.

And it's like, when you release all these illegal aliens, especially criminals, we are talking about -- we are not talking about law-abiding illegal aliens -- we are talking about criminals on the streets -- it's very dangerous.

And public safety is very, very important in Orange County. And it's going to hurt. And it's going to hurt our residents in Orange County, and not just Orange County, but for California.

CAVUTO: Do you think California is hurting itself, hurting its reputation by doing this, the mayor of Oakland, the governor who support these type of measures?

STEEL: Oh, my God, yes.

Mayor of Oakland tells everybody that this is racist. That has nothing to do with it. We don't want any criminals walking on the street.

You cannot really put it some different way, but we just want to stop these criminals walking on our streets.

CAVUTO: You always get that rap, right? I mean, and I have talked to others who are trying to do the same thing as you are, Michelle.

And the first thing they have to deal with is, oh, you're racist, or you're against poor people trying to do the right thing in the United States. And they morph into saying you're against immigration, of course, when you're against illegal immigration.

But you know the drill. Have you gotten any of that?

(LAUGHTER)

STEEL: I know the drill. And I know the process. I'm a first-generation immigrant.

And Orange County is number third, the largest county in the state. And we have a lot of large immigrant communities in our county. So we totally understand.

And we are supporting that what we are doing, because left-wing California state legislators, and they're the ones created this chaos. And we have to stop that. So what we are doing is, Jeff Sessions sued California.

And I don't want this going to be inside of the court forever. And we want to expedite the ruling against this bad law.

CAVUTO: All right, Now, it should be stressed that you're in a conservative community. Most of the communities in California seem to be slightly to the left of you.

So, it's not really going to change the policy in the state, or do you suspect it might?

STEEL: No, I want all the 58 counties in California joined us.

And there's a couple of cities already joined us. And Newport Beach, city of Newport Beach, you heard, and Buena Park is, and then Aliso Viejo in Orange County, they all start this.

So, all these cities and counties joining us opt out against this bad law, then I think it's going to happen. It's not just like all the leftists and the other counties, but they all want to be in the safe environment.

CAVUTO: All right, Michelle Steel, thank you very much for taking the time, Orange County, California, supervisor.

And, again, she's an example of some in the state there saying, whoa, whoa, whoa, whoa, we need a sanctuary from the sanctuary thing. It's fascinating and it's building.

We do want to alert you as well. We told you about these roughly $55 billion to $66 billion worth of trade tariffs that administration slapped on the Chinese. Well, they are responding, as we thought they would, that China is strongly disappointed and firmly opposes the president's move, strongly disappointed that he's doing this, that plans for Chinese imports are a bad idea.

Going on to say, he doesn't want a trade war with the United States, but will not recoil from one. This is again coming from the Chinese Embassy in Washington. China would fight to the end with all necessary measures in a trade war initiated by the U.S.

Now, again, the prevailing wisdom is that they go for something that will hit back at the president, some of these agricultural targets that might hurt the presidents in states that he won and hurt Republicans in states that they have generally done well in the last election in the midterm.

There's no way of quantifying that. There is also a suspicion that Boeing might be a target. It was among the worst performers in the Dow 30 today, on the belief that the Chinese might say, we're not going to order planes from you. We will go to Airbus.

There's no way of knowing, but that the Chinese have responded, as we thought they would, and that they're saying they're not guilty of any of this and that China doesn't, doesn't do any of the horrible things they have been accused of doing from this administration.

By the way, this administration is not the first one to say that the Chinese cheat. It's the first administration to act on it.

We will have more after this.

CAVUTO: Remember that guy? Well, he's live right now. You're looking live at Steve Bannon.

He's speaking at The Financial Times conference going in New York City. The man accused of a whole lot of leaks has been out of the White House, but those leaks keeps coming.

So the White House wants to start trying to get handle on this. How does this keep happening? Steve is gone, but they're still happening.

What the heck is going on?

Let's ask former Deputy Assistant to President George W. Bush Brad Blakeman.

They do have a problem here. Marco Rubio articulated it very well, Brad, to say, look, if you don't want to be in the administration, you don't like the president, or you don't like just being there, get the hell out. But it still happens.

What's going on?

BRAD BLAKEMAN, FORMER PRESIDENTIAL ADVISER: Well, what is going on is, we have people within the White House that are trying to deep-six the president on his policies.

If they don't like it, what do they do? They leak it and try and either sink the policy or adversely affect it. But there's a way to stop it, Neil.

And it's pretty simple. Every bit of paper the president gets, there is a flow chain, a check-off of who has this information. I think the president needs to get serious. Get the FBI in. Do interviews, polygraphs if necessary, and find out who these people are, and deal with them harshly, because it will send a tremendous message throughout the White House that leaking is inappropriate.

Get fired. Get prosecuted, if necessary. That's the way to get a handle on leaking.

CAVUTO: These are relatively small and apparently increasingly smaller groups of people. So at least you could remember, I was at a meeting with six other people. I know I wasn't the guy doing the leaking, so maybe the other five did.

It's like a bad version of the game "Clue." But, I mean, what do you do? I mean, how do you get a handle on it? Because this is not the administration that has had this sort of problem, but it seems to me here to be out of control.

BLAKEMAN: But you have to make examples of people.

And, sometimes, administrations don't want to know who the leaker is, because they're afraid of who it might be. Now you need to send a message, not only to the White House, but to the bureaucracies, that leaking is not going to be tolerated.

And, again, whether it's a telephone call, there's a checklist of people who are on that call it, you do check the box. Is it this person? Is it that person? Is it this person?

The other problem, Neil, is, I may be privy to information, and then I give it to somebody else within the administration, who then leaks it. But then you have a paper trail, you have a telephone trail. This is something that can be done forensically. And the FBI does this all the time. It probably should be done now,.

CAVUTO: The one thing is really weird about it is that -- and this dates back to remember when the president just got in office and a call that he had, it was a nasty exchange with the Australian prime minister? And suddenly -- very few people were aware of that, maybe, say, people at the State Department. Maybe it was someone at the State Department.

And it was all over, their argument, that they said it.

And back to Marco Rubio's point. If for some reason this is all about embarrassing the president or you don't like the president, then stop working for the president.

BLAKEMAN: There's no doubt about it.

But it may not be people directly in the White House. It could be somebody in the bureaucracy who is not necessarily politically appointed by the president, a career person. And you can find out that as well.

But no leaking should be tolerated, whether it's...

CAVUTO: But, see, what you said there is interesting, because someone then would be tapping the president, tapping the president's phone.

BLAKEMAN: Well, not really.

You would be surprised, Neil, on, let's say, a call with Putin. Typically, there's probably about 10 people on that call.

CAVUTO: Wow.

BLAKEMAN: There are translators. There are notetakers.

CAVUTO: Well, that's true.

BLAKEMAN: But, again, you know from the call sheet who exactly is privy at firsthand information to that call.

The FBI needs to go out and polygraph these people. And you're going to find the leaker pretty quick.

CAVUTO: Do they still rely on these polygraphs?

BLAKEMAN: Absolutely. And they're done randomly, as well as drug testing. You don't know when it's coming. And that's the way it should be, because then you can't prepare for it.

CAVUTO: You know what I do? I look at everybody's eyes, like -- you ever do that? And if they're shifting, I just say, you -- I don't know.

BLAKEMAN: Then everybody in Washington would be locked up.

CAVUTO: Well, you know, actually, it was a dumb point I just made there. Thank you for bringing that up.

(LAUGHTER)

CAVUTO: Brad, thank you very, very much, Brad Blakeman, former deputy assistant to President George Bush -- W. Bush.

BLAKEMAN: Pleasure.

CAVUTO: All right, in the meantime, we have got some new developments involving some intelligence leaks and the former director of national intelligence, James Clapper. Remember him?

Catherine Herridge in Washington with the latest on that.

Hey, Catherine.

CATHERINE HERRIDGE, FOX CHIEF INTELLIGENCE CORRESPONDENT: Thank you, Neil.

Earlier today, Republicans on the House Intelligence Committee posted more extensive findings from their investigation, because now the 150-page report goes to the intelligence community for declassification.

I have some of those findings right here. And one in particular is noteworthy under a section about national security leaks and the allegation -- it says -- I'm reading from it -- the former director of national intelligence, James Clapper, this is the person who runs the intelligence community and is charged with protecting classified information.

Republicans found that he provided -- quote -- "inconsistent testimony" about his contacts with the media, including CNN.

That's important, because, of course, now he works as an analyst for CNN. And based on our reporting, we believe the incident at issue here is that January 2017 Trump Tower briefing, where the incoming president was told for the first time about this unverified dossier.

And it was the leaking of that briefing which really took the dossier story into the mainstream, which is something that hadn't happened in the fall of 2016, Neil.

CAVUTO: You know what is kind of interesting, Catherine?

If you think of Clapper and you think of Brennan, and you think of all of these former higher-ups at all these various intelligence agencies, we now know how they feel about the president, Brennan, over-the-top criticism of the president.

And the president have always argued, these guys are biased against me. It turns out, if their sentiment is pretty consistent, he was right

So what are we to make of their prevailing view, which tends to be very dismissive of President Trump, and whether that in one way, shape or form at any of these intelligence agencies of which he was quite critical is coming back to bite him?

HERRIDGE: Well, a couple of points there.

In the past, I have tried to reach DNI Clapper for comment on other FOX reporting, but he has declined, citing his new position with CNN. So we will try again, because that's the right thing.

But in the past, he's not provided comment.

The other thing I would say, that in the 15 years that I have been covering the intelligence community here in Washington, I have never seen a period where previous leadership has been so public and outspoken and really very political about their views of a current administration.

So that is certainly a new and very different development, Neil.

CAVUTO: And petty, right, very, very petty.

HERRIDGE: Well, you have to look into their eyes, right?

(LAUGHTER)

HERRIDGE: I almost feel nervous about this segment now, what my eyes are telling you.

CAVUTO: I'm watching you.

HERRIDGE: I know.

CAVUTO: I am watching you.

(LAUGHTER)

CAVUTO: All right, Catherine, thank you very, very much.

HERRIDGE: You're welcome.

CAVUTO: That is so weird, Catherine Herridge.

(LAUGHTER)

CAVUTO: But, if you think about it, folks, the president has been saying, right, look, these guys have it out for me.

And, sometimes, like my dad used to say, it's a good thing to be paranoid, because you really should be seeing who is right over your shoulder, because there are a lot of cases again and again where they're telling exactly how they feel about the president now, in a former -- former top official role.

Well, what was the deal when they were those top officials at all these various security agencies and they harbored those views? The only difference is, they're not in power to do that. Of course, some of them pop up on other news networks just to rip him a new one, but that's a whole 'nother drama.

In the meantime, there's where we stand going into tomorrow. A lot of concerns about how this sorts out. Friday, anything could happen. You know what's going to happen in Asia and Europe. We will see.

"The Five" now.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5Y38-J261-JDJN-624J-00000-00In the 5G era, China has taken the lead as the west has failed to keep up2020-01-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:02:37ZLexisNexisIn the 5G era, China has taken the lead as the west has failed to keep upMustafa Alrawi

Huawei has emerged as the dominant force. And for the the US to now win, it will have to be more nimble and work smarter than China

A sign advertising 5G mobile telecommunication in a shop in London. Britain is hoping to negotiate a comprehensive free-trade agreement with the United States after Brexit, but a number of thorny issues stand in the way. Justin Tallis / AFP

Washington's campaign to dissuade nations around the world to refrain from using China's Huawei in building their fifth-generation mobile networks is stalling.

Despite the argument put forward by the US that the Chinese company could one day be a security threat (an argument the latter strongly refutes), Britain said on Tuesday it is to allow Huawei limited access to its future 5G network. On Wednesday, the EU was also expected to shy away from a ban on the Chinese company's technology. These decisions recognise the truth that if you want 5G and its super-fast internet speeds then you have little option but to turn to Huawei.

Development of new technology should not be left to either the public or private sector to decide alone

If there were a real alternative to Huawei in terms of equipment for 5G, this wouldn't be a debate.

Europe led in the 2G era, Japan led 3G and the US led 4G. Now it is China's turn.

It is worth noting ever since 2G first allowed for secure and ubiquitous voice and SMS, there has been a fair amount of hysteria around the adoption of subsequent generations of cellular technology – both positive and negative. 5G is no different, even if it is expected to provide us with a fully interconnected society.

Huawei, ahead of Cisco in the US, Europe's Nokia and Ericsson, Japan's Rakuten and South Korea's Samsung, has emerged to become the dominant force in this area of communications technology. While Huawei disputes the accusation it receives preferential treatment from the Chinese government, what cannot be disputed is that the unique environment created in China is what allowed it to become the world's largest maker of telecoms equipment.

Equally indubitable today is that the US and Europe have lost the 5G battle to China. The question now is are they also losing the wider war to lead a digital future?

According to Bloomberg, the US is the ninth most innovative country in the world. Seven years ago, it was ranked first. China is only at 15th, but is rising. More than half the top ten is made up of European nations like Germany, which is number one, and Switzerland, which is fourth. South Korea and Singapore are second and third, respectively.

The scale of an economy is not necessarily an arbiter of success in innovation, but the wider takeaway of the Huawei story is that the development of new technology should not be left to either the public or private sector to decide alone.

The market cannot be trusted to put strategic areas of development ahead of profit when necessary, and governments are rarely efficient or competitive enough to develop anything on their own.

Apple, Qualcomm, Cisco and Intel have failed to lead the worldwide push into 5G. Lucent and Motorola were unable to remain competitive over the years. This is partly because the economics of new investment didn't always make sense, especially when one is already ahead of the pack in the prevailing technology of the day. Another reason is that the government has a role to play in encouraging the adoption of the next generation of technology even if it isn't profitable yet and Washington seems to have dropped the ball on 5G. That is despite the rich tradition of public-private partnership in the innovation of new technologies in America.

Founded by Alexander Graham-Bell, the inventor of the telephone, Bell Labs – ironically enough now owned by Nokia – pioneered research into the transistor, semiconductors and microwaves in the last century. Work carried out at Bell Labs underpins much of modern computing and communications. Its efforts were indirectly funded by the government through the telephone monopoly that the lab's parent AT&T enjoyed. There were also institutions across the states that were fuelled by government funding directly – one example being Stanford University, from which today's hotbed of innovation Silicon Valley has evolved.

Read More

Thanks to 5G, this is the decade we graduate from the smartphone

Apple 'to introduce 5G iPhones in 2020' but is unlikely to increase cost

Big tech companies like Facebook and Google have grown to dominate thanks to the explosion of mobile communications. Their phenomenal success today, however, may hamper breakthroughs in the future. Big companies don't behave like start-ups and often fail to innovate even when they have an advantage. That's why government regulation also has to be right. Lessons have been learned from how fractured standards for mobile telephony became in the US.

On to the next battlegrounds. For example in artificial intelligence, the US and China are ahead of Europe.

Although, China has the upper hand, first and foremost thanks to a huge population from which to take the data sets that inform AI. For much the same reason, it also has a bigger talent pool from which to hire. The US will have to be more nimble and work smarter than China in order to win. It seems Washington is making sure that the public and private sectors – linking up government, universities and companies – have every opportunity to work together as a matter of policy. For AI at least it is not being left up to the market alone to decide how technology develops in the US.

Mustafa Alrawi is an assistant editor-in-chief at The National

Updated: January 29, 2020 03:40 PM

Aired 8-9pm ET2019-01-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:02:37ZLexisNexisIn the betting markets, Beto O'Rourke is now the favorite to win the Democratic nomination, says Tucker; Beto O'Rourke posted his dentist visit on Instagram; 'You will ensure death,' said Beto O'Rourke of Trump's proposed Border wall, in a Washington Post interview; Liberal media calls Republicans racists; Center for Immigration Studies files RICO lawsuit against Southern Poverty Law Center; Google manipulated YouTube search results for abortion, reported Breitbart; Tucker investigated Google's influence on elections; Yellow Vests rattle the French establishment; 'It's a demand for democracy,' said Christophe Guilluy on Yellow Vests' demands, in Spiked Online interview; Tucker debated with Marijuana advocate, David Bienenstock; President Trump jokes about First Lady 'making salads' for players, and CNN Panel melts down over it. Aired 8-9pm ETLanhamFULL TEXT

BERNARD WHITMAN, DEMOCRATIC PARTY POLITICAL POLLSTER AND STRATEGIST, PRESIDENT AND FOUNDER OF WHITMAN INSIGHT STRATEGIES: And if a brand can stand up and say be the best a man can get, then--

MARTHA MACCALLUM- ANCHOR: Yes.

WHITMAN: --then I think that furthers (ph) the conversation and helps to bring the country further together (ph).

And number two, this tells us that Sundar Pichai, Google CEO, committed perjury when he testified before Congress a few weeks ago, because he said quite specifically that Google never does this.

CARLSON: So, I mean I - my frustration levels are so high, I don't want to take it out on you. But the first thought is well, why isn't he being recalled back to Congress to explain himself or face charges because you're not allowed to commit perjury.

But my question is can any of us trust that the next election won't be swayed dramatically in one direction by interference from the tech companies?

EPSTEIN: I guarantee you that this past election was affected. I'll be releasing some - some data on this, I hope, in early March that'll make the point beyond any doubt.

I also just published a piece in which I showed that just one manipulation on Google's part, on Election Day, their Go Vote reminder, that one reminder, that Go Vote reminder shifted between 800,000 and 4.6 million votes to Democratic candidates on Election Day in 2018.

CARLSON: So, why - why isn't this the hacking of our democracy? I mean how can you have a democracy under these circumstances?

EPSTEIN: Well, democracy is a kind of illusion at this point because we have let these companies, Google more than any other, go completely wild. There are no rules, no regulations, no laws that restrict anything they do.

And again, the more one looks at what it is they're actually doing, and these new leaks help a lot, in my opinion, the closer one looks at what they're doing, the more outraged one should become.

And I want to emphasize, we should all be outraged, not just Conservatives.

CARLSON: Yes. I - I agree. I hope that what you just said pings around the internet unimpeded and winds up in the inbox of every Member of Congress on both sides. Robert, thank you very much.

EPSTEIN: My pleasure, always.

CARLSON: Why is nobody covering this? It's a great question. And this question as well. Google's manipulation, the one we just told you about, why isn't that a violation of campaign finance law? The companies YouTube blacklist, for example, allegedly suppress negative videos about Maxine Waters. Why is that not an in-kind contribution to Maxine Waters?

Harmeet Dhillon, unlike us, is an attorney, and she joins us tonight. So, Harmeet, you just saw a guy plead to a felony because he paid off his client's girlfriend with private funds in the middle of a campaign. That was considered a campaign finance violation.

Here you have the most powerful company in the world, putting its thumb on the scale on behalf of candidates, but that's not a campaign contribution? How?

HARMEET DHILLON, CIVIL RIGHTS ATTORNEY, FORMER VICE CHAIRWOMAN OF THE CALIFORNIA REPUBLICAN PARTY AND THE NATIONAL COMMITTEEWOMAN OF THE REPUBLICAN NATIONAL COMMITTEE FOR CALIFORNIA: Well it is a campaign finance violation. And - and if anybody thinks that this is some sort of aberration, Google has been doing this and bragging about it internally, even in the last election.

Tucker, I think, your show has previously covered the fact that Google made what, I think, one internal person at Google, a Manager at Google called silent campaign contribution by turning out the vote and contributing turnout the vote efforts in several states that were swing states for Hillary Clinton, and specifically targeting Latino voters.

I think people should be encouraged to do Democratic activities like this on both sides and help with elections.

But when a corporation does it with its corporate assets, it needs to be dis - disclosed as a campaign finance violation, declared and disclosed on the other side as a campaign finance receipt by the campaign.

Here, you have the one example of Maxine Waters. But let's just play - let's just play this out. Now, we have about 20-plus Democrats running for - for the Democratic nomination.

If Google decides to bump up the search engine results in a positive way for Beto O'Rourke in response, for example, to Democratic candidates for President 2020, and then bump down Tulsi Gabbard or some others, for example, that's going to be a contribution, and that contribution, in - in my opinion, to those candidates who benefit from it, and a very valuable one.

And if it isn't being disclosed as such, then that is a fraud on our democracy. And you can then imagine what they're doing vis-a-vis Donald Trump.

They're already doing it to Republicans as we - you have previously reported with regard to search engine results for Republican Women, for California Republican Party, for various other Republicans. So, I think this is, you know - you know, we all think every story is important when it comes to Google and what they do online.

But this is a particularly shocking and alarming story that we really need to see our Members of Congress, Senators and the White House wake up about this issue because otherwise we aren't going to be talking about a democracy in the next two election cycles.

We'll be talking about what it used to look like before we let Big Tech takeover and control the outcome.

CARLSON: I - I don't see how under these circumstances, all things being equal, Donald Trump could get re-elected. I don't. And look, I mean I think we should have a free and fair election where people's votes really matter.

But under these circumstances, we're not going to have that. I wonder why the White House wouldn't - I mean they do control the Executive Branch of government. Why they wouldn't have been awakened to that but.

DHILLON: We have seen Donald Trump actually tweet about this issue in September 2018. He tweeted about, frankly, the subject matter of today's story from Breitbart and, you know, people called him a - a conspiracy theorist that it isn't true.

And, you know, now we see the evidence that actually they are doing this manipulation, and that Sundar Pichai lied to Congress about it.

CARLSON: Yes.

DHILLON: But - but these companies skillfully spread the money around, not just to Members of Congress, but also people working in an Administration, who are looking for their exit and thinking--

CARLSON: Exactly.

DHILLON: --"Well maybe I'll work on the other side of tech policy and make a bunch of money advising Google on how to speak Conservative--

CARLSON: Scary. Scary.

DHILLON: --to Conservatives."

CARLSON: That's exactly right.

DHILLON: That's how it happens.

CARLSON: Vladimir Putin is a much smaller threat to the United States than Google, I would say.

DHILLON: Absolutely.

CARLSON: Harmeet Dhillon, thank you very much.

DHILLON: My pleasure.

CARLSON: Christophe Guilluy is a well-known author in France. He's written a number of books about that country's middle and working classes. He recently gave a long interview to a website called Spiked about the Yellow Vest demonstrations there that have convulsed French society, and terrified the French government.

Our media haven't said very much about the Yellow Vests, and that should not surprise you. Ostensibly, their protests are a reaction to global warming taxes and speed cameras.

But as Guilluy explains, what you're actually watching is a revolt against a deeply selfish and stupid establishment, and that very much includes the media. Listen to his analysis here, and ask yourself if it sounds at all familiar.

"Fifteen years ago, I noticed that the majority of working-class people actually live very far away from the major globalized cities, far from Paris, Lyon and Toulouse, and also very far from London and New York.

Technically, our globalized economic model performs well. It produces a lot of wealth. But it doesn't need the majority of the population to function. It has no real need for the manual workers, laborers and even small-business owners outside of the big cities.

Paris creates enough wealth for the whole of France, and London does the same in Britain. But you cannot build a society around this.

What the Yellow Vest protestors have in common is they live in areas where there is hardly any work left. They know that even if they have a job today, they could lose it tomorrow, and they won't find anything else.

They are also culturally misunderstood by the elite. One illustration of this cultural divide is that most modern, progressive social movements and protests are quickly endorsed by celebrities, actors, and the media and the intellectuals. But none of them approve of the Yellow Vests.

Their emergence has caused a kind of psychological shock to the cultural establishment. It is exactly the same shock that the British elites experienced with the Brexit vote and that they are still experiencing now, three years later.

Many voters wanted to remind the political class that they exist. That's what French people are using the Yellow Vests for, to say "We exist." We are seeing the same phenomenon in populist revolts across the world.

All the growth and dynamism is in the major cities, but people cannot just move there. The cities are inaccessible, particularly thanks to mounting housing costs. The cities have become very unequal, too.

The Parisian economy needs executives and qualified professionals. It also needs workers, predominantly immigrants, for the construction industry and catering etcetera. Business relies on this very specific demographic mix.

The problem is that the people outside the cities still exist. The non-urban population actually encompasses the majority of French people.

We have a new bourgeoisie, but because they are very cool and progressive, it creates the impression that there is no class conflict anymore. It is really difficult to oppose the hipsters when they say they care about the poor and about minorities.

But actually, they are very much complicit in relegating the working classes to the sidelines. Not only do they benefit enormously from the globalized economy, but they have also produced a dominant cultural discourse, which ostracizes working-class people.

Think of the "deplorables" evoked by Hillary Clinton. There is a similar view of the working class in France and Britain. They are looked upon as if they are some kind of Amazonian tribe. The problem for the elites is that this is a very big tribe.

The reaction to the Yellow Vests has been telling in France. Immediately, the protesters were denounced as xenophobes, anti-Semites and homophobes. The elites present themselves as anti-fascist and anti-racist.

But this is merely a way of defending their class interests. It is the only argument they can muster to defend their status, but it's not working anymore. Now the elites are afraid.

A lot has been made of the fact that the Yellow Vests' demands vary a great deal. But above all, it's a demand for democracy. Fundamentally, they want to be taken seriously and they want to be integrated into the economic order.

We need a cultural revolution, particularly in the universities and in the media. They need to stop insulting the working class, to stop thinking of them as imbeciles.

Cultural respect is fundamental. There will be no economic or political integration until there is cultural integration. Then, of course, we need to think differently about the economy. That means dispensing with neoliberal dogma. We need to think beyond Paris, London and New York."

Well if you found yourself, as you heard that, thinking that Guilluy was talking about your country, not France, there's a reason. In many ways, he was. Imagine what it would look like if our Republican leaders understood what you just heard. They might start winning elections.
